Bruxelles, le 2 Mars, 1891
Monsieur le Ministre, J'ai l'honneur de vous présenter cettre requête sollicitant le titre de Consul de l'Etat Independant du Congo pour les Etats Unis d'Amerique.
Belge de naissance, habitant l'Amerique depuis bientot sept ans familliarisé avec la langue et les usages de ce pays, comme ayant aussi les capacités commerciales et qualités requises pour de telles fonction j'ose esperer, Monsieur le Ministre, que vous voudrez bien donner suite à ma demande et m'accorder cette position que je sollicite et attends de votre bienveillance.
A titre de references je vous dirai, Monsieur le Ministre, que je represente pour les Etats Unis d'Amerique plusieurs maisons de commerce et industries importantes de Belgique, entre'autres la maison J. Moëus, distillerie d'Anvers et Messess et fils de Surnhout, avec proprietaires de ces deux grandes fabriques je suis rataché par les biens de famille.
Esperant que Monsieur le Ministre me fera l'honneur d'une audience au cours de laquelle je pourrai donner de vive voix les references que j'ai, ainsi que plaider auprès de lui les qualités et apttudes par rapport aux fonctions que je sollicite, J'ai l'honneur d'être, de Monsieur le Ministre, le très humble Serviteur, J. div1.p: Brussels 2.26.91

Mister Minister Mr. B. Vicq of Lunoptoch prays that I recommend him to you. The man showed much ener- gy and by his work he has achieved in supporting a bountiful family. I only had excellent records on his mora- lity.
, Mister Minister, the place of my senti- ments highest consideration Moreau
United States
Mister Van Eetvelde Administrator General of the department of Foreign Affairs and Minister of the Justice of the Free State of the Congo in Brussels.
Brussels, March 2, 1891
Mister Minister, I have the honor to present you with this request solliciting the title of Consul of the Independent State of the Congo for the United States of America.

Belgian in birth, living in America for nearly seven years familiarised with the language and the customs of this country, as having as well the commercial capacities and required qualities for such function I dare to hope for, Mister Minister, that you follow up on my demand and accord to me this position that I sollicit and await from your benevolence.

In title of references I will tell you, Mister Minister, that I represent for the United States of America several houses of commerce and important industries of Belgium, among others the house of J. Moëus, distillery of Antwerp and Messess and son of Surnhout, with owners of these two large factories I am associated by the links of family.

Hoping that the Minister will do me the honor of an audience over which I can give with a lively voice the references that I have, as well as plead with him the qualities and aptitudes in relation to the functions that I sollicit, I have the honor to be, for Mister Minister, the very humble servant, J. B de Vicq de Cumptich.
To Mister van Eetvelde Administrator General and Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Independent State of the Congo in Brussels.
Mister Minister, I left Brussels March 14th of last after having paid a last visit to Mister C. Janssens and having regretted not to have been able to present you my civilities before my departure.

I sold the journal of which I was owner in Nova Scotia and I currently am taking care of the chair of the writing of the Mail of the New World, and I expect, under little, to make the acquisition of this last paper, the most widespread and the most important of frenc publications published in the United States.
I will be grateful to you, Mister Minister, to

inform me of all the documents on the Congo, documents that would permit me to do an extensive study on the question hanging between this state and the United States of America, in order to be able to have need to treat the question in the Mail of the New World as well in the large american journals of New York and Boston.

Being in journalism, It would be a pleasure and make me happy to be useful to the State of the Congo, in the weak measure of my forces and of my sphere of action, not having any other ambition, Mister Minister, destiny not having favored me to be under the flags, that to serve my country, in putting under its disposition my weak capacities and my work, not estimating too happy, if in reward for my efforts I could know that the Sovereign of the Free State of the Congo is content with me and the I obtain from His Majesty Leopold the sollicited post by his humble subject of which I would fill the duties faithfully.

Hoping, Mister Minister, that in your bounty you will not forget the humble request that I addressed to you during February of last, that request which was intent by Mr the Governor General of the State of the Congo, Mr. C. Jansses, and Mr. Knight of Moreau d'Andoy, old minister of agriculture and Director general of the National Bank, I hold to your disposition some letters of
recommendation of Members of the Senate and the American Federal Chambers, as well as from distinguished journalists from the United States with whom I am associated.

In the wait of a word from your part, Mister Minister, and the hope to be named to the post that I solliited et that I await from your benevolence, and in assuring you of my respectful sentiments, I have the honor to be for Mister Minister, the very humble servant. Baron. J. B. de Vicq de Cumptich
To Mister Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Free State of the Congo. In Brussels. Belgium.
32 Jackson Street. Worcester. Mass. U.S. May 1 1891
